project.teaser: European rural areas, face societal, demographic, economic and environmental pressures due to global transformations and crises. They are in need of a renewal by social innovation that increases their resilience and reduces the adverse effects on their socio-economic and...
project.objective:
European rural areas, face societal, demographic, economic and environmental pressures due to global transformations and crises. They are in need of a renewal by social innovation that increases their resilience and reduces the adverse effects on their socio-economic and environmental sustainability. Unbalanced development impacts their populations’ lively-hoods and well-being in general, but it affects the most those people who are already in precarious and fragile positions.
SERIGO produces evidence-based theoretical and practicable knowledge on how the Social and Solidarity Economy (SSE) can support resilience, social inclusion, and ‘good life’ in European rural areas. Based on the research results produced, the aim is also to provide insights and recommendations on what framework conditions and policy arrangements are necessary to promote this, as well as to trigger constructive debates and collaborations around this issue involving diverse set of stakeholders in Europe.
The project applies an intersectional perspective to vulnerability, as well as implements critical systems thinking in combination with community-based participatory research to investigate potentials of the social economy in promoting social inclusion and in enhancing the quality and accessibility of services in rural areas. Empirical data is gathered in a high number of qualitative case studies from 13 countries on social economy solutions implemented in local contexts. Using the multi-actor approach, SERIGO benefits from more nuanced and ’live’ insights into the drivers of social exclusion offered through the lenses of local stakeholders working together with researchers on co-created experimental pilots in five European regions. SERIGO ensures also with a system of deliberate feedback loops, dedicated multi-level policy workshops and a sustained thematic community of practice that the new knowledge generated is pertinent and applicable, and all its outputs have high exploitable potential.
project.title: Social Economy for Resilience, Inclusion and Good life in Rural areas
project.keywords: empowerment of vulnerable groups, rural areas, social economy, social entrepreneurship

article.title: Practical solutions to revitalise rural resilience

result.title: D1.1 Initial Integrated Conceptual Framework
result.description: Assessing on a conceptual level the interlinkages between vulnerabilities/capabilities, social ex-/inclusion and SSE solutions in relation to the aim of achieving ‘good life’, sustainability and resilience in diverse rural contexts.

result.title: D7.2 Project monitoring plan
result.description: Ensuring the sound implementation of the project, to support the work of the individual teams and WP leaders and to early identify and handle problems in carrying out the work packages.

result.title: D5.1 Project website
result.description: Serving as the primary online platform for public communication, gateway to key project activities, and a library of open-access materials.

details.publisher: Publishing House of the Comenius University

result.title: D2.1 Cross-cutting analytical dimensions and guidelines
result.description: Defining cross-cutting research themes and questions – to support WP3 and WP4 coordinators in ensuring that research in case studies and pilots will bring outputs in a form amenable to triangulation and synthesis within WP2.

result.title: D3.1 Guidelines for field research, case study analysis and database
result.description: Specific research inquiries and guidelines for data collection and analysis (incl. stakeholders mapping tool, interview guidelines, policy analysis matrix, and shared case study database).

result.title: D4.1 Guidelines for the co-creation and research of inclusive and empowering pilot actions
result.description: For pilot implementation and action research incl. needs mapping, co-creation lab. methodology and self-reflection, internal and cross-pilot knowledge exchange and template for reporting.

result.title: D5.2 Communication, Dissemination and Exploitation Plan
result.description: To support, ensure and monitor dissemination and exploitation of results as well as visibility and communication of activities.

result.title: D7.1 Data management plan
result.description: Document describing the handling, storage, and solutions for preserving data during and after the end of the project, as well as accessibility policy.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
